Key Arguments: The bill grants the government unprecedented powers to curb free speech.
The legislation conflicts with the UN's Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the Australian Human Rights Commission's recommendations.
The definition of 'harm' is subjective and determined by bureaucrats, potentially leading to enforced ideological conformity.
The bill could be used to restrict public debate and censor unpopular opinions.
There is a historical precedent of misuse of power by totalitarian governments, which this bill could facilitate.
Notable Quotes: This bill would give the government unprecedented powers to curb free speech according to the views of a select group of government-appointed bureaucrats.
The most likely ultimate effect of this would be to enforce ideological conformity.
This bill threatens to close down legitimate free speech and empower future dictators.
